text: Table I Causes of rhabdomyolysis Traumatic Crush injury and trauma (earthquakes, collapsed buildings, road traffic collisions) Compartment syndrome (alcohol-associated immobility, prolonged collapse, perioperative positioning, prolonged tourniquet use) Electrocution Non-traumatic Exertional (strenuous exercise, seizures) Body temperature changes (malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, hypothermia) Genetic defects (ranging from disorders of glycolysis or gluconeogenesis to disorders of the mitochondria) Drugs or toxins (statins, alcohol, heroin, cocaine) Infections (influenza A and B, EBV, HIV, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus) Metabolic and electrolyte disorders (non-ketotic hyperosmotic state, diabetic ketoacidosis) Idiopathic
